It was a place of quiet routines and deep, tangled histories, his own included. He pulled his father’s book from the glove compartment, the leather cool in the night air. He didn’t need the torch anymore. He sat in the cab of his ute, the faint glow from the dashboard illuminating the pages, and read the underlined verses, hearing them now not just in his father’s voice, but in his own. He was beginning to understand that his father's struggle wasn't about leaving, but about holding onto the memory of home while being a world away. He wasn't chasing his father's ghost into a grave anymore; he was walking beside him, finally understanding the weight he had carried. The horizon wasn’t an escape; it was a duty, and the town below wasn't a prison, but an anchor, a reminder of the quiet, ordinary world that soldiers exist to defend.

The two weeks of leave bled away with the slow, inevitable pace of a receding tide. The awkwardness with his mother softened into a quiet, sad routine. They found a new, narrower ground on which to meet, talking about the weather, his future posting in Darwin, the practicalities of his new life, carefully avoiding the emotional minefield of why he had chosen it. On his last night, she cooked a farewell dinner, a simple meal filled with a profound and unspoken significance. As he was preparing to leave in the morning, she pressed a small, worn photograph into his hand. It was a picture of him as a boy, no older than ten, sitting on his father’s shoulders. His father, home on leave and dressed in civilian clothes, was beaming, his face open and full of a simple, uncomplicated joy. Lachlan was laughing, his small hands tangled in his father’s hair. “He was so proud of you, Lachie,” she said, her voice thick with tears she refused to shed. “Remember that. Whatever you do, wherever you go, remember that you were his horizon, too.”

The next morning, the goodbye at the airport was quieter than the one at the train station had been. The arguments were over, the grief settled into a permanent, aching reality. This time, when she hugged him, it was not with desperation, but with a fragile, heartbreaking acceptance. “Be safe,” she whispered, her cheek against the rough fabric of his uniform. He nodded, unable to speak past the lump in his throat. As he walked towards the departure gate, he didn't look back. He was a soldier now, and soldiers are taught to march forward. He found his seat on the plane, the photograph and his father’s book the only personal effects in his carry-on. As the plane taxied down the runway and lifted into the air, he looked out the window. His hometown, the place of his birth and his rebellion, shrank below him, becoming just one more feature in a vast, sprawling landscape. The road forward was clear. He was flying north, towards the heat and the dust, towards a new life in a new army, a Sapper on his way to join his regiment. He was no longer running from a fire. He was flying towards a purpose he had built for himself, piece by painful piece.The plane descended through a thick, soupy blanket of cloud, and the first glimpse of the Northern Territory was not of rugged outback, but of a sprawling, swampy green. It was a landscape that seemed to be actively trying to consume the neat grids of suburban streets and industrial estates carved into it. The moment the cabin door opened in Darwin, the air hit Lachlan with the force of a physical blow. It was a solid wall of heat and humidity, so thick and wet it felt like he was breathing through a damp cloth. It tasted of salt, jet fuel, and decaying vegetation. This was a different world, governed by a different, more oppressive sun. The comfortable, dry air of New South Wales was a distant memory, a luxury he hadn't known he possessed.

The bus to Robertson Barracks was old and its air-conditioning fought a losing battle against the oppressive climate. Lachlan sat by a window, watching the landscape roll by. Everything was drenched in a hyper-saturated, almost lurid colour palette: the rust-red of the soil, the aggressive green of the tropical foliage, the bleached-out blue of the sky. The base itself was vast and sprawling, a city unto itself, but it lacked the claustrophobic, high-pressure feel of Kapooka. This was a working base, not a factory for breaking civilians. The soldiers he saw walking between the low, functional buildings moved with a lazy, heat-induced languor, but their professionalism was evident in the way they carried themselves, their uniforms faded and softened by countless washes, their faces tanned and etched by the northern sun. They were not recruits. They were professionals at work.

He was dropped, along with a handful of other new arrivals, at an administrative building where a corporal with a bored expression and a deep, mahogany tan processed their paperwork with minimal enthusiasm. From there, another corporal, this one younger and with a perpetually cynical smirk, drove him in a battered Land Rover to the lines of the 2nd Combat Engineer Regiment. “Welcome to the madhouse, chock,” the corporal said, his first words to Lachlan. “Rule number one: the heat’s trying to kill you. Rule number two: so is everything else. Rule number three: don’t piss off the boomer.” Lachlan, unsure what a ‘boomer’ was, decided the safest response was a quiet nod. The Land Rover pulled up outside a series of long, elevated accommodation blocks, known universally as ‘dongas’. This was his new home.

The room he was assigned was small and spartan, a significant step up from the open barracks yet somehow more lonely. It contained two beds, two metal lockers, and two desks, all bolted to the floor. A powerful, rattling air-conditioner in the wall fought a constant, noisy war with the heat. His roommate was already there, a wiry, sandy-haired Sapper named O’Connell, who was lying on his bunk in a pair of shorts, reading a well-thumbed paperback. He looked up as Lachlan entered, his eyes making a quick, professional assessment of the new arrival. “You must be Jones,” he said, not getting up. “I’m O’Connell. But everyone calls me Dingo. Your bunk’s that one. Don’t put anything on the floor, the geckos will piss on it.” He went back to his book, the conversation apparently over. Lachlan stowed his gear in the empty locker, the metallic clang echoing in the small space. This was it. No welcome speech, no orientation. He was just a new part, slotted into a vacant space.

The following morning, Lachlan reported to his troop lines for the first time. The building was a large, open-sided shed, part workshop, part office, part social club. It smelled of diesel, grease, and welding fumes. Men were scattered around, cleaning weapons, servicing vehicles, and engaging in the time-honoured military tradition of drinking copious amounts of tea while complaining about their superiors. Lachlan stood awkwardly near the entrance until a corporal with a neat, compact build and a calm, authoritative air approached him. His name tape read ‘FRANKS’. “Sapper Jones,” he stated, his voice quiet but firm. “I’m Corporal Franks, your section commander. Welcome to Three Troop.” He shook Lachlan’s hand, his grip strong and dry. “Your roommate Dingo will show you the ropes, get you squared away at the Q-store. We’re on vehicle maintenance for the rest of the week. Don’t touch anything until you’re told to, don’t break anything, and if you’ve got nothing to do, find a broom. Clear?” “Clear, Corporal,” Lachlan replied, the familiar response feeling solid and reassuring.

The rest of the day was a blur of mundane, essential tasks. He was introduced to the Troop Sergeant, a grizzled veteran with a face like a clenched fist who looked at him as if he were something unpleasant he’d scraped off his boot. He met the Troop Commander, a fresh-faced Lieutenant who seemed barely older than Travers and spoke with the clipped, eager enthusiasm of someone who had read all the right books but had yet to face a real test. Led by a laconic Dingo, he spent hours in the quartermaster's store, a vast, dim warehouse, being issued a mountain of new equipment specific to the tropical environment and his engineering role. He signed for everything from mosquito nets and water purification tablets to specialised demolition kits and mine detectors. Each signature was another link in the chain binding him to this new life. The work itself, back at the troop lines, was unglamorous. He found himself cleaning mud from the tracks of an armoured personnel carrier, the repetitive, mindless task a stark contrast to the high-minded purpose he had felt on graduation day. He was a janitor again, just in a different uniform, mopping up the messes of a different machine.

That night, alone in his room while Dingo was out with friends, the full weight of his dislocation settled upon him. The oppressive heat, the constant hum of the air-conditioner, the sterile anonymity of the room, and the cynical, closed-off nature of his new colleagues all conspired to make him feel more isolated than ever before. He was a thousand miles from home, a stranger in a strange land, and the clear, simple purpose he had clung to during training felt distant and hazy. He pulled a writing pad from his locker, intending to write to his mother, but stared at the blank page, a familiar paralysis taking hold. How could he describe this life? The boredom, the casual cynicism, the overwhelming sense of being a novice in a world of hardened experts? He couldn’t tell her about Dingo’s casual profanity or the Troop Sergeant’s look of utter contempt. He couldn’t explain the feeling of being utterly insignificant. So he fell back on the facts, the sterile language of a military report. *Arrived safely in Darwin. The base is big. I’ve been assigned to my troop. The work is interesting.* He sealed the letter, the words feeling like a betrayal of his own reality.

Frustrated, he picked up the poetry book. He let it fall open to a random page and his eyes fell on a poem he hadn't noticed before, "A Bush Christening," about a rough-and-tumble outback family. There was a faint pencil mark next to a line describing the father: *“He was none of your dolts, he was sharp as a needle.”* Lachlan sat back, considering the line. It wasn't about being strong or brave. It was about being sharp, about being switched-on, about surviving in an environment that punished foolishness. He looked around the sterile room, at the pile of unfamiliar, technical equipment he had been issued, and thought of Corporal Franks’ quiet competence, Dingo’s cynical but observant nature, the Troop Sergeant's unspoken demand for absolute professionalism. This wasn't Kapooka, where the challenge was to endure. This was a different kind of test. The challenge here was to be sharp. To learn, to observe, to prove that he was not a dolt, but a useful, competent part of the team. The road forward wasn't a grand, heroic charge; it was a slow, patient accumulation of knowledge and trust, one mundane task at a time. The loneliness didn't disappear, but a new, clearer sense of purpose began to crystallise within it. He was not here to be a hero. He was here to be a Sapper. And the education had just begun.The education of a Sapper began not with a bang, but with a broom. Every morning, after a run in the soupy, pre-dawn humidity that left him feeling like he was drowning on dry land, Lachlan’s first duty was to sweep the vast concrete floor of the troop shed. He was the newest arrival, the ‘chock’, a term he’d learned meant a raw, inexperienced soldier, and therefore the designated custodian of menial tasks. While the veteran Sappers gathered around the large, battered urn for their first mug of tea, their conversation a low, cynical murmur, Lachlan would push the wide broom, collecting a film of red dust, grease, and the detritus of the previous day’s work. He didn't resent it. He understood its purpose. It was a tax he had to pay for entry, and it gave him the perfect opportunity to do what he did best: observe. He learned the names of the other men in his section not through formal introductions, but by listening to the banter. There was ‘Dingo’ O’Connell, his cynical roommate; ‘Knuckles’ Petrie, a slab of a man with a shaved head and a surprisingly gentle touch with delicate electronics; and ‘Shades’ Williams, a quiet, wiry Sapper who never seemed to be without his wraparound sunglasses, even indoors. And then there was Corporal Franks, their section commander, who moved through the morning chaos with a quiet, watchful economy, his presence a low hum of authority that didn't require a raised voice.

The work itself was a slow, grinding immersion in the tools of his new trade. Days were spent on vehicle maintenance, a greasy, frustrating education in the guts of armoured personnel carriers, generators, and outboard motors. Dingo became his begrudging instructor, a fount of cynical, hard-won knowledge. "If you round off a bolt, the Boomer will use it to screw your head back on straight," he’d mutter, watching Lachlan struggle with a seized nut. "Never stand behind an excavator when Knuckles is driving. And if you have to choose between getting wet and getting electrocuted, take the wet." The advice was always delivered with a world-weary sigh, as if the effort of passing on wisdom to someone so clueless was almost too much to bear. But Lachlan listened. He learned to differentiate the healthy roar of a diesel engine from the unhealthy clatter that preceded a breakdown. He learned the feel of a properly torqued bolt, the precise language of the technical manuals, and, most importantly, when to ask a question and when to keep his mouth shut and figure it out for himself.

The mystery of the ‘Boomer’ was solved in his first week. The Troop Sergeant, a man whose permanent scowl seemed to be a load-bearing feature of his face, was conducting a spot inspection of their work. He stopped at a Land Rover where Knuckles had just finished servicing the brakes. For a full minute, the Sergeant stared at the wheel hub in absolute silence, his stillness drawing the attention of the entire shed. Then he reached out a single, thick finger and tapped the brake calliper. “Petrie,” he said, his voice a low, gravelly rasp. “You’ve used a grade five bolt on this calliper mount. The manual specifies a grade eight. Do you know the difference in shear strength between a grade five and a grade eight bolt?” Knuckles, who dwarfed the Sergeant, seemed to shrink, his face turning a mottled red. “No, Sergeant,” he stammered. The Sergeant leaned in close. “It’s the difference between this vehicle stopping at the bottom of a hill, or you and your mates becoming a new coat of paint on a rock wall. It’s the difference between a soldier and a liability. Now, which one are you?” He didn't wait for an answer. He simply turned and walked away. A cold silence descended on the shed. Later, as Lachlan was cleaning grease from his hands with a solvent-soaked rag, Dingo leaned against the workbench. “That,” he said quietly, “is the Boomer. That’s why you don’t fuck up.”

Lachlan’s first small test, when it came, was over a piece of equipment so insignificant it was almost laughable. The section was preparing for a riverine exercise, and one of the Zodiac’s outboard motors was proving temperamental. It would start perfectly, run for ten minutes, then sputter and die for no apparent reason. Dingo and Shades had pulled the carburettor apart twice, their curses growing more creative with each failure. Corporal Franks stood watching, his arms crossed, his expression one of patient frustration. Lachlan, tasked with cleaning the boat’s inflatable pontoons, was on the periphery, but his ears were tuned to the problem. The symptoms were naggingly familiar. It was like a fire that kept flaring up in a wall cavity; there was a hidden fuel source, a hidden fault in the system. He put down his sponge and walked over, his heart thumping with the fear of overstepping his mark. “Corporal,” he began, his voice hesitant. Franks turned his steady gaze on him. Dingo shot him a look that said, *don’t you dare*. Lachlan pushed on. “When a two-stroke runs fine then cuts out when it’s hot, sometimes it means a failing crank seal. It’s drawing air when the casing expands, leaning out the fuel mix.” He had seen the same principle a dozen times with the petrol-powered rescue saws at the fire station.

A heavy silence fell over the small group. Dingo scoffed. “It’s a brand-new motor, chock. The seals are fine.” But Franks didn’t dismiss it. He looked from Lachlan to the motor, his brow furrowed in thought. “How would we test that theory?” he asked, his question directed squarely at Lachlan. The direct engagement was both terrifying and exhilarating. “When it’s hot and running rough, you can spray a bit of starter fluid around the crankcase housing. If the revs pick up, it’s sucking the fluid in through a bad seal.” It was a bush mechanic’s trick, a piece of practical knowledge from a different life. Franks considered this for a moment, then nodded. “Alright. Let’s try it.” They ran the motor until it began to sputter. As instructed, Franks gave a quick, targeted spray of aerosol starter fluid near the crankcase. The engine, which had been on the verge of dying, suddenly screamed back to life for a few seconds before faltering again. The proof was undeniable. Dingo stared at the motor, then at Lachlan, his mouth slightly agape. Corporal Franks straightened up and wiped his hands on a rag. “Good spot, Jones,” he said, the words delivered with no more inflection than a weather report. He then turned to Dingo. “Pull it apart. Get a new seal kit from stores.” For the rest of the day, Lachlan felt a quiet, internal hum of satisfaction. He had been sharp. He had been useful.

That evening, as the section was packing up, Dingo paused at the door of their donga. Lachlan was sitting on his bunk, cleaning his rifle, the familiar, methodical task a comfort at the end of a long day. “Oi, Jones,” Dingo called out. “Me and the boys are heading to the boozer for a counter meal. You coming?” The invitation was gruff, almost a challenge, but it was an invitation all the same. It was the first time he had been included. Lachlan looked up from his rifle, a slow smile spreading across his face. “Yeah,” he said, trying to match the casual, offhand tone. “Yeah, righto.” As he followed Dingo out into the warm, insect-rich twilight, he felt a lightness he hadn't experienced since he had left home. The loneliness was still a quiet hum in the background, but for the first time, it was being drowned out by the feeling that he was, finally, exactly where he was supposed to be.The pub, a cavernous, air-conditioned shed just off base, was an extension of the troop lines, only with more alcohol and fewer rules. The section claimed a corner table, their collective presence creating an invisible perimeter that other soldiers instinctively respected. The conversation flowed around Lachlan, a raw, cynical stream of complaints about the food, the officers, the heat, and the sheer, bloody stupidity of a recent directive from on high. It was a litany of grievances that served as a form of social glue. Dingo held court, his stories punctuated by dry wit and a flair for the dramatic. Knuckles would interject with a low rumble of agreement, while Shades, true to his name, observed from behind his sunglasses, offering only a rare, wry smile.

Lachlan mostly listened, nursing a cold beer, a student of this new culture. He learned that the Troop Sergeant’s nickname, ‘The Boomer’, came from his previous service in a mortar platoon. He learned that the Lieutenant was known derisively as ‘The Textbook’ because his every decision seemed to come from a manual rather than experience. He learned that the unspoken code of the Sapper was to complain relentlessly about the work, but to take immense, ferocious pride in its execution. He was an outsider listening in, but for the first time, he was an outsider who had been invited inside the circle.

“So, Jonesy,” Knuckles rumbled, turning his attention to Lachlan for the first time that evening. The use of a nickname, however generic, was a significant step. “Dingo reckons you’re some kind of engine whisperer. Used to be a grease monkey?”

“Firefighter,” Lachlan corrected, the word feeling strange on his tongue. “Worked with a lot of two-stroke rescue gear. Saws, pumps. They’re all temperamental bastards.”

“Firefighter, eh?” Shades spoke up, his voice a surprising baritone. He took a slow sip of his beer. “So you’re used to running into burning buildings. Explains why you’d volunteer for this gig. Got a death wish?” The question was blunt, but it lacked malice. It was a genuine inquiry.

Lachlan considered the question. A few months ago, it would have stung, a direct hit on a raw nerve. Now, it felt like a question about a different person. “Something like that,” he admitted with a shrug. “Got tired of mopping up messes. Figured I’d rather build something for a change.”

“We don’t build things, mate,” Dingo snorted, slamming his empty glass on the table. “We blow things up. Then maybe, if The Textbook draws the plans right, we build something out of the wreckage. It’s a cleaner kind of mess, that’s all.” He grinned, a flash of white teeth in his tanned face. “But the pay’s alright and the explosions are pretty. Another round?” As Lachlan nodded, he realised he had passed another, unspoken test. He had given an honest, unvarnished answer that fit their cynical worldview. He wasn’t trying to be a hero. He was just another bloke looking for a cleaner mess. The small act of Dingo getting the next round was a confirmation. He was in.

The "cleaner mess" arrived a week later in the form of Exercise Sapper’s Strike. The objective was simple and brutal: to destroy a series of obsolete concrete structures deep in the Mount Bundey Training Area, a vast, heat-scorched territory south of the base. The structures, remnants of a Cold War-era radar station, were thick, reinforced bunkers, designed to withstand everything short of a direct nuclear strike. Their task was to reduce them to rubble, a practical test of their demolition theory.

The approach to the site was a mission in itself. They moved in a small convoy, their Land Rovers churning up clouds of fine red dust that coated everything in a gritty film. The landscape was primordial, a flat, savanna-like plain punctuated by towering termite mounds that looked like a thousand silent, red sentinels. The heat was a living entity, pressing down on the canvas roof of the vehicle, radiating up from the metal floor. Corporal Franks briefed them at the site, his voice sharp and precise against the backdrop of the incessant chirping of cicadas. He pointed to the first objective, a low, squat concrete bunker half-swallowed by the encroaching bush. “This is Bunker Alpha. Your task is to calculate and place charges for a complete structural collapse. You will use PE4 plastic explosive with a dual-primed ring main. Lachlan, you’re on calculations and charge prep. Dingo, you and Knuckles will drill the charge holes. Shades, you’ll run the det cord. No mistakes. The Boomer and The Textbook will be observing from that ridge line.” He pointed to a low, stony rise a few hundred metres away, where two figures were already visible, small and menacing in the shimmering heat haze. “Do not make me look bad.”

Lachlan felt a knot of cold, focused excitement tighten in his stomach. This was it. The theory from the classroom, the dry formulas and blast ratios, were about to become a physical, violent reality. He knelt in the shade of a lone Woollybutt tree, his field notebook open, the plastic explosive cool and pliable in his hands. He calculated the volume and density of the concrete, factored in the reinforcing steel, and determined the precise mass of explosive needed for each charge. The process was a form of intricate, high-stakes mathematics. Too little, and they would only scar the bunker. Too much, and they would send shrapnel flying for a kilometre. He worked methodically, his hands moving with a new-found confidence as he moulded the PE4 into precisely weighed charges, carefully inserting the detonators, the small, potent hearts of the explosion.

As Dingo and Knuckles drilled into the thick concrete with a heavy, petrol-powered rock drill, its roar echoing across the plain, the sky began to change. The bleached-out blue darkened to a bruised purple on the horizon. The air grew heavy and still, the cicadas falling silent. “Build-up,” Shades muttered, nodding towards the approaching storm front. “She’s coming in fast.” The wet season was stirring, and its first storms were notoriously violent. The wind picked up, whipping dust and leaves into a frenzy. A few fat drops of rain splattered onto Lachlan’s notebook, smearing the ink. Franks swore under his breath. “Double time, let’s go! I want this rigged before the storm hits!”

The urgency escalated. The first crack of lightning split the sky, followed by a deafening clap of thunder that seemed to shake the very ground beneath their feet. The rain began in earnest, a torrential, blinding downpour that turned the red dust to a slick, greasy paste. Visibility dropped to a few metres. They were working in a primal chaos of wind and water. Lachlan, shielding his prepared charges with his own body, helped Shades run the det cord, their fingers numb and clumsy in the deluge. The cord, a thin, explosive line, had to be connected to each charge in a precise, unbroken sequence. A single faulty connection would compromise the entire shot. They scrambled back to the designated safe distance, unreeling the firing cable, their boots slipping and sliding in the treacherous mud. Crouched in a shallow ditch, Corporal Franks looked at each of them, his eyes intense. “All clear?” he yelled over the wind. One by one, they gave a thumbs-up. Franks took the electrical firing device, the ‘clacker’, and turned to Lachlan. “Your numbers, your shot, Jones.” He handed him the device. The responsibility was a physical weight in his hands. He took a deep, steadying breath, his heart pounding a rhythm against his ribs that matched the fury of the storm.

He knelt in the mud, the firing device feeling both alien and deeply familiar. It was a tool designed for a single, irreversible purpose. His world shrank to the small, red button under the protective guard. He ran through a final mental checklist: the calculations, the placement of the charges, the integrity of the ring main. He thought of the storm, the rain potentially compromising the connections. He thought of the two figures watching from the ridge, a jury of his superiors. He thought of his mother, a world away, and the photo of him as a boy on his father’s shoulders. Then he pushed it all aside. There was only the task, the science, and the trust placed in him by his section commander. He looked at Franks, who gave him a single, sharp nod. He lifted the guard, took one more breath to steady his hand, and yelled the ritual words into the roaring wind, a shout of defiance against the storm itself. “FIRE IN THE HOLE!” He squeezed the trigger.

For a split second, nothing happened. The world was just the drumming of the rain and the howl of the wind. Lachlan’s heart seized in a moment of cold, sickening dread. Had he failed? Then, the ground beneath them kicked, a violent, solid punch that travelled up through the soles of his boots and into his teeth. A deep, guttural *CRUMP* sound, more felt than heard, momentarily deadened all other noise. The bunker, which had stood impassively for half a century, seemed to swell from within. A web of cracks raced across its surface, and then it simply collapsed, folding in on itself like a house of cards in a silent, slow-motion ballet of destruction. A plume of grey dust and smoke, instantly beaten down by the torrential rain, rose from the wreckage. A beat later, the sound of the blast rolled back over them, a physical wave of pressure that flattened the grass and rattled their bones.

They lay in the ditch for a moment, the rain washing over them, the sudden silence where the bunker had been more profound than the noise that had preceded it. Dingo let out a low whistle. "Jesus, Jonesy. You don’t do things by halves, do you?" Lachlan felt a slow, shaky exhale leave his lungs, a breath he hadn't realised he was holding. He had done it. His numbers had been right. His hands, he noticed, were trembling, but not from fear. It was the pure, visceral aftermath of adrenaline, the same singing in his veins he had once felt after a fire, but this was different. It was the satisfaction of a job planned and perfectly executed. It was creation through destruction.

Corporal Franks clapped him on the shoulder, a hard, solid impact. "Good shot, Sapper," he said, the use of the formal title a mark of profound respect. He looked out at the pile of shattered concrete and twisted rebar. "Clean collapse. Minimal throw. The Boomer will be happy." The rain was already starting to ease, the storm passing as quickly as it had arrived. As they stood up, their bodies caked in mud, a rainbow, impossibly vivid, arched across the bruised sky directly over the site of the demolition. Knuckles let out a hoot of laughter. "Would you look at that? Even God likes a good explosion."

That evening, back at the barracks, the atmosphere was light, almost festive. They were exhausted, filthy, and facing hours of cleaning their sodden equipment, but they were buoyed by the shared success. The story of ‘Jonesy’s shot’ had already made its way around the troop lines, embellished with each telling. Lachlan found himself the quiet centre of a new level of acceptance. He was no longer just a competent mechanic; he was a Sapper who could be trusted when the stakes were high. As he sat on his bunk, painstakingly cleaning the red mud from the firing device, he felt a sense of belonging so deep it was almost painful. He had found his place, not in a safe, predictable life, but here, on the sharp edge, among these cynical, profane, and fiercely loyal men.

Later, before sleep, he pulled out his writing pad. The letter to his mother felt different tonight. He still couldn't describe the raw, visceral reality of his day, but he found new words. *We had a big training exercise today. It was a demolition task. It was my job to calculate the charges. It was complicated, but it went well. I’m learning a lot. The blokes in my section are good men. It’s hard work, but I think I’m good at it.* He paused, then added a line that was both a reassurance for her and a truth he was just beginning to accept for himself. *I feel like I’m finally building something.* He sealed the envelope and then, almost as an afterthought, he reached for his father's poetry book. He didn't open it to read. He simply placed his hand on the worn leather cover, feeling the solid weight of it in the darkness. The ghost of his father felt less like a shadow to be chased and more like a quiet, approving presence at his side. The road forward was no longer a abstract concept; it was a path he was walking, one explosion at a time.The success of Exercise Sapper’s Strike bought Lachlan more than just a momentary feeling of accomplishment; it bought him a currency more valuable than pay in the ecosystem of the barracks: respect. He was no longer the ‘chock’ on broom duty. The broom was now the responsibility of a fresh-faced recruit just arrived from Kapooka, a kid with bewildered eyes who looked at Lachlan and the rest of the section with a mixture of terror and awe. Lachlan now joined the sacred morning ritual around the tea urn, a silent participant in the litany of complaints that served as the troop’s daily prayer. He learned to nod along as Dingo bemoaned the quality of the rations, to grunt in agreement when Knuckles cursed a piece of faulty equipment, and to appreciate the profound silence with which Shades could communicate his utter contempt for a newly issued directive. He was part of the circle, his entry fee paid in full with a perfectly executed demolition in the middle of a tropical thunderstorm.

The weeks that followed settled into a rhythm of intense training punctuated by long stretches of the peculiar boredom unique to army life. They practiced their core skills relentlessly. Days were spent on the ranges, the sharp crack of their rifles a constant, rhythmic punctuation to the oppressive heat. They rehearsed casualty evacuation under simulated fire, the drills so ingrained that they could apply a tourniquet or dress a wound with a mechanical, almost indifferent efficiency. Lachlan’s aptitude for the technical side of his trade continued to grow. Corporal Franks began to delegate more complex tasks to him, first under supervision, then with an unspoken trust. He learned the intricate wiring of command-detonated explosives, the delicate art of neutralising booby traps, and the patient, nerve-wracking process of searching for mines. He discovered he had a natural feel for the work, a combination of the firefighter's methodical risk assessment and a newfound soldier's discipline. His hands, which had once been calibrated to the heft of a Halligan bar, were now learning the delicate touch required to probe for a tripwire.

The announcement of their next major deployment came without fanfare during a morning briefing. The Platoon Sergeant, the Boomer, stood before them, his arms crossed over his chest, his presence casting a long shadow in the early morning light. The Textbook stood beside him, holding a clipboard and looking eager. The Boomer ignored him. “Listen up,” he growled, his voice cutting through the quiet murmur of the troop. “Two Platoon is being attached to Bravo Company from the 5th Battalion for Exercise Arnhem Thunder. It’s a full-spectrum combat team exercise. Infantry, armour, engineers, the whole circus.” He paused, letting the information sink in. “Our primary task is mobility support. Specifically, lane clearance. Bravo Company needs a safe path through a valley in the Litchfield Training Area. Intel suggests the valley is notionally mined. Your job is to clear it.” He scanned the faces of the assembled Sappers, his eyes lingering for a moment on Lachlan’s section. “One more thing,” he added, his voice dropping slightly. “This area was a major live-firing range during World War Two. It was never fully cleared. The ground here has a long memory. Keep your eyes open for anything that looks older than you are. Real-world unexploded ordnance is not notional. It will kill you just as dead. Franks, your section is lead element. Don’t stuff it up.”

The mood in the section shifted immediately. The casual cynicism was replaced by a quiet, focused professionalism. A notional minefield was a straightforward training task, a matter of following procedure. The potential for real, seventy-year-old UXO changed the entire equation. A training mine gives off a clear signal on a detector. A corroded, half-buried artillery shell from 1943 might give off nothing at all. It was a task that relied less on technology and more on instinct, observation, and pure, nerve-shredding luck. As they began the meticulous process of preparing their equipment, Lachlan watched Corporal Franks. The man’s calm demeanour never wavered, but there was a new intensity in his actions. He personally inspected every piece of their clearance gear, from the sensitive electronic heads of the mine detectors to the simple, non-metallic prodding rods. He checked the expiry dates on their demolition charges, the ones they would use to destroy any UXO they found. He was a man methodically preparing his tools for a task where a single mistake, a single moment of inattention, could vaporise his entire section. Lachlan felt a profound respect for the quiet, immense weight of responsibility Franks carried on his shoulders.

That afternoon, a new mail delivery arrived. Lachlan received a letter from his mother, and for the first time, he opened it without a sense of dread. The tone was different. The desperate, emotional pleas were gone, replaced by a sort of bruised acceptance. She wrote about her garden, about a funny thing Marcus had said, about how she’d seen Gaz’s wife at the supermarket. *Gaz said to tell you they’re all proud of you,* she wrote. The sentence stopped Lachlan short. Pride was not an emotion he had associated with his departure. She continued, asking practical questions about Darwin, about the food, about whether he was getting enough sleep. It was the letter of a mother learning to communicate with a son who now lived in a different country. But the final lines held the familiar, aching love that would always be the anchor of his old life. *I read your last letter to Marcus. He said it sounds like you’ve finally found what you were looking for. I hope he’s right. I pray for it every day. Just be safe, Lachie. Always be safe.* He folded the letter and put it carefully in his locker. He hadn’t found what he was looking for; he had built it, out of sweat and fear and the quiet approval of the men around him. And now, he had to prove he was worthy of it.

The final twenty-four hours before deployment were a quiet hum of activity. They drew their specialised gear, the mood in the Q-store more like a hospital dispensary than a supply depot. The mine detectors, with their long, sensitive arms, were treated with a reverence usually reserved for religious artifacts. They packed their webbing with marking tape, trip-flare indicators, and small, potent ‘Mecar’ charges designed for UXO disposal. The atmosphere was a world away from the boisterous energy that had preceded the demolition exercise. This was not a task that would end with a satisfying bang and a round of beers. This was quiet, patient, terrifying work. The enemy was not a reinforced bunker, but a ghost in the ground, a piece of rusted, unstable history waiting for a single misstep.

As the sun began to set, casting long, dramatic shadows across the barracks, Lachlan sat on his bunk, going through his own personal prep. He field-stripped and cleaned his rifle for the third time, the familiar, repetitive action a calming ritual. Heka sat opposite him, sharpening a large sheath knife on a whetstone, the rhythmic *shick-shick-shick* a steady, meditative sound in the quiet room. “You nervous, Jonesy?” Heka asked without looking up, his first unsolicited question in weeks. Lachlan paused his cleaning. “A bit,” he admitted. “You?” Heka stopped sharpening and looked at the blade, its edge gleaming in the low light. “Nervous is good,” he rumbled. “Nervous keeps you sharp. Scared gets you killed. There’s a difference.” He tested the blade on his thumb, nodded in satisfaction, and slid it back into its sheath. “This is the job, eh? To walk quiet. To look close. You’re good at that.” The simple statement of confidence from the big, silent man was more reassuring than any pep talk from an officer. It was an acknowledgment from one professional to another.

They were woken long before dawn. They moved in the darkness, their movements economical and sure, their gear making only the softest of sounds. They loaded into the back of a troop-carrier truck, the four men of the section sitting shoulder-to-shoulder on the hard bench seat. As the truck rumbled out of the barracks and onto the long, straight road leading to the training area, no one spoke. The first, pale light of dawn was beginning to illuminate the eastern sky. Lachlan looked at the faces around him, illuminated in the faint glow of the dashboard lights. Dingo’s cynical smirk was gone, replaced by a grim, focused intensity. Knuckles stared straight ahead, his jaw set. Shades was already wearing his sunglasses, a black, impenetrable mask. And Corporal Franks sat by the tailgate, his rifle across his lap, his gaze sweeping the passing landscape, already on the job. Lachlan felt a surge of cold, clear purpose. These were his men. This was his section. And they were heading into the valley, to clear the road forward, to walk quiet and look close, into a silence that held the memory of a long-forgotten war.

The smoke was a living thing. A grey, cancerous beast that clawed at the throat and bit at the eyes. It had texture, a greasy weight that settled on the skin and worked its way into the pores. Lachlan Jones knew its every mood. The lazy, almost thoughtful curl of a smouldering mattress. The frantic, black panic of burning plastic. This one was angry. A mean, bitter smoke born of old timber, thirty years of dust, and a family’s worth of accumulated life going up in a roar of incandescent rage. He and his partner, Gaz, moved through the house with the practiced economy of men who danced with fire for a living. Water thundered from the nozzle of the hose, a brute force against a brutal element, turning the world to a hissing, steaming chaos.

The heat was a physical blow, a solid wall you had to push against. It pressed on his chest, wrapped around his limbs. Through the visor of his helmet, the room was a nightmare canvas of orange and black. A floral armchair, a place where someone had read the paper or watched the telly, was now a shrieking effigy of flame. Lachlan swept the jet of water across it, beating it back, taming it into a sulking, black ruin. The comms in his ear crackled. “Second floor clear, Captain. Structural integrity is... questionable. We’re pulling back.”

“Copy that,” Lachlan grunted, his own voice sounding distant. He and Gaz were on the ground floor, the engine room of the inferno. Gaz gave a two-fingered signal, a quick chop towards the door. Time to go. The fight was won, now came the slow, dirty work of mopping up. As they backed out onto the scorched lawn, the cool night air was a shock, a sudden dousing in reality. He pulled off his helmet, the release of pressure a small mercy, and scrubbed a hand over his soot-blackened face. The air still tasted of ash. On the driveway, a child’s plastic tricycle had melted into a grotesque, weeping sculpture. Red and yellow plastic, now a Dali-esque puddle on the asphalt. He stared at it for a moment too long. Another close call. Another family standing on the curb watching their world burn down. Another job done. And a hollow space, right in the centre of his chest, where the adrenaline used to sing. Now, it just echoed.

“Reckon that’s the third dodgy wiring job this month,” Gaz said, collapsing onto the rear bumper of the truck and pulling a bottle of water from the cooler. He was a decade older than Lachlan, his face a roadmap of smiles and sun damage.

“Something like that,” Lachlan replied, his gaze still on the ruined house. The fire was out, but the beast wasn't dead. It was just sleeping, waiting for the next faulty switch or forgotten cigarette. He felt less like a dragon slayer and more like a janitor, endlessly mopping up the same predictable messes. He’d joined the New South Wales Fire and Rescue to save lives, to be on the front line. And he was. But the line felt… circular. A holding pattern of suburban disaster. He’d seen more blazes started by unattended deep-fryers than by any real malice. The enemy wasn't a dragon. It was complacency. It was bad luck. It was mundane.

Driving home an hour later, the truck’s heater blasting to ward off the post-exertion chill, the smell of smoke clung to him like a second skin. It was in his hair, his clothes, the very fabric of the ute’s seats. He passed the glowing signs of late-night takeaways, the empty bus stops, the quiet, sleeping houses with their porch lights on. Safe. For now. He reached into the glove compartment, his fingers brushing past a street directory and a half-eaten packet of mints, until they found the glossy pamphlets. He’d folded them in half so the bold lettering wasn’t immediately visible. *Australian Army. Challenge Yourself.* He pulled one out at a red light, the face of a determined-looking soldier in camouflage staring back at him from under a coat of grime. The man’s eyes were clear. Focused. He wasn’t looking at a burning house. He was looking at a horizon.

His mother, Sarah, had left the light on for him. The house was quiet, smelling of lavender spray and the lamb roast she’d kept warm in the oven. It was a familiar comfort, but tonight it felt like a tether. She was in her armchair, a book face-down in her lap, her head tilted at an awkward angle in sleep. Her face, so familiar to him, looked fragile in the dim light. He stood there for a moment, the heavy weight of his decision pressing down, a different kind of heat from the fire. He knew this would burn her.

He gently cleared his throat. Her eyes fluttered open. “Lachie. You’re back. Was it a bad one?”

“Just another day at the office, Mum,” he said, forcing a casualness he didn’t feel. He walked into the kitchen and pulled the plate from the oven, the warmth seeping into his cold hands. He didn't have an appetite, but he knew she'd worry if he didn't eat. He sat at the small kitchen table, the silence stretching between them, punctuated only by the hum of the refrigerator.

“You’re quiet,” she said, coming to stand in the doorway, tying the sash of her worn dressing gown.

Lachlan put his fork down. The piece of lamb was suddenly impossible to swallow. He looked at the recruitment pamphlet he’d left on the counter. He hadn’t meant to, but there it was. Accusing him.

Sarah’s eyes followed his. She walked over, picked it up as if it were something venomous. Her face, which had been soft with sleep, hardened. “What is this?”

“Mum…”

“Lachlan, what is this?” Her voice was sharper now, the edges brittle.

“It’s what it looks like,” he said, his own voice low. “I’ve been thinking. I’m going to enlist.”

The silence that followed was worse than the roar of any fire. It was absolute, a vacuum that sucked all the warmth from the room. She just stared at him, her expression crumbling. “No,” she whispered. It wasn't a command. It was a plea. “No. Not after your father. Lachie, you can’t.”

“This has nothing to do with Dad.”

“It has everything to do with him!” Her voice rose, cracking. “He went looking for a challenge too. He went looking for a horizon. And where did it get him? A flag folded in a triangle and a letter from a man who’d never even met him. You have a good job, a life here. You save people here!”

“I put out fires in chip pans, Mum! I pull cats out of trees! It’s not the same.”

“Is that what you think? That those people in that burning house tonight don’t think you’re a hero? That their lives aren’t worth saving because their fire wasn't ‘challenging’ enough for you?”

He flinched. The words hit their mark. “That’s not what I mean.”

“Then what do you mean, Lachlan? That you want to go somewhere far away and get yourself shot at by people you’ve never met? For what? For a line in a history book? I’ve already buried a husband in the name of some far-flung cause. I will not bury my son.” Her hands were shaking as she clutched the pamphlet, crumpling it into a ball. Tears welled in her eyes, bright with anger and terror. “I won’t let you.”

“You can’t stop me,” he said, the words tasting like ash in his mouth. “I’m a grown man.”

“Then be one! Don’t be a boy chasing his father’s ghost into a grave!”

The doorbell rang, a sharp, jarring chime that sliced through the tension. They both froze, staring at each other, their argument hanging in the air between them like smoke. Lachlan felt a surge of raw, indefensible anger. His mother looked broken. He pushed his chair back and went to the door, yanking it open with more force than necessary.

Standing on the porch, bathed in the yellow light, was his step-brother, Marcus. He was the polar opposite of Lachlan’s world. Dressed in a tailored dark shirt and expensive-looking jeans, he smelled faintly of sandalwood and whiskey. His hair was perfectly styled, his smile was easy and immediate. Marcus was a creature of cool interiors, of hushed conversations in dimly lit bars and the rustle of theatre programs. He managed The Royal, the old art-deco theatre downtown that had been brought back from the brink of demolition and was now the surprising cultural heart of the town.

“Whoa,” Marcus said, holding up his hands in mock surrender, his smile faltering slightly as he took in Lachlan’s soot-stained face and the raw emotion in the room behind him. “Walking into the lion’s den, am I? Just came to drop off that bottle of wine I promised you, Sarah. Bad time?”

Sarah flinched as if struck, her hand flying to her mouth to stifle a sob. She quickly wiped at her wet cheeks, her posture straightening as she tried to pull a mask of normalcy over her shattered expression. Lachlan remained rooted by the open door, a pillar of simmering fury and soot. The sudden shift from the raw, elemental conflict of the fire to this intricate, painful domestic battle left him feeling wrong-footed and exposed.

“Marcus,” Sarah said, her voice thin but polite. She forced a watery smile that didn’t reach her eyes. “Sorry. You’ve just caught us at the end of a long night. Come in, don’t stand on the step.”

Marcus stepped over the threshold, his easy smile replaced by a look of cautious concern. He was holding a bottle of red wine by the neck, a peace offering from another, calmer world. His eyes flickered from Sarah’s distraught face to Lachlan’s rigid stance, then down to the crumpled ball of paper lying on the floor by the kitchen table. He was too perceptive not to feel the shockwave of the argument he’d walked into. The air was still vibrating with it.

“I can come back,” he offered, his voice low and diplomatic. “It’s no problem.”

“Nonsense,” Sarah insisted, taking the wine from him. Her hand trembled slightly as she clutched the bottle. “Thank you. This looks lovely. We’ll have it with Sunday lunch.” The mention of a future that felt suddenly uncertain hung in the air. She turned to the kitchen, desperate for a mundane task to perform, placing the bottle on the counter with deliberate care.

Lachlan hadn’t moved. The contrast between himself and his step-brother had never felt so stark. He was covered in the filth and stink of destruction, his muscles aching, his heart a hollow drum. Marcus was clean, calm, smelling of things that were chosen, not inflicted. He represented a life of curated experiences, of art and conversation, a world Lachlan felt increasingly alienated from. A world his mother desperately wanted for him.

The small talk was an agony. Marcus, trying to bridge the chasm, asked, “Big one tonight?”

Lachlan just grunted in affirmation, his gaze fixed on the wall behind Marcus’s head. He could feel his mother’s pleading stare on his back, begging him to play along, to pretend. But the pretence felt like another layer of suffocation. The casual question trivialised the roaring beast he’d just fought, the terror in the homeowner’s eyes, the melted tricycle that was now a permanent image burned onto his memory.

“I’m heading out,” Lachlan said abruptly, the decision crystallising in an instant. He needed air that didn't smell of lavender and unspoken grief.

“Lachie, wait,” Sarah said, her voice tight with panic. She came out of the kitchen, her hands fluttering helplessly. “You haven’t finished your dinner. You need to eat.”

“Not hungry,” he clipped out, finally moving. He brushed past Marcus, deliberately avoiding eye contact, and grabbed his keys from the hook by the door. The simple action felt like a final, definitive severing.

“Lachlan!”

He ignored his mother’s cry and pulled the door open, stepping back out into the cool night. The slam of the door behind him was unnervingly final. It cut off her voice, leaving him alone with the hum of the streetlights and the churning in his gut. He hadn’t resolved anything. He had just run, leaving a new kind of wreckage in his wake. He got into his ute, the smell of smoke-infused fabric rising up to greet him like a grim accomplice. He didn’t start the engine. He just sat there in the dark, his hands gripping the steering wheel, the echo of his mother’s plea louder than any fire alarm. *I will not bury my son.*

Back inside the house, the silence was absolute. Sarah stood frozen in the middle of the living room, her face pale. Marcus watched her, his earlier ease completely gone. He was out of his element, a spectator to a tragedy he didn’t have the script for. His gaze fell again to the crumpled pamphlet on the floor. Gently, he bent down and picked it up. He smoothed the creased paper out on the kitchen counter. *Australian Army. Challenge Yourself.* The determined soldier’s face stared up at him. He looked at Sarah, whose carefully constructed composure was finally breaking apart, her shoulders shaking with silent sobs.

“Sarah?” he asked softly, his voice full of a quiet dread. “What has he done?”

Sarah’s breath hitched, a ragged, tearing sound in the quiet kitchen. She sank into one of the kitchen chairs, the one Lachlan had just vacated, and buried her face in her hands. The sobs were no longer silent; they were wrenching, guttural expressions of a fear she had kept locked away for years. Marcus stood awkwardly for a moment, the polished bottle of wine on the counter a useless totem of a normal evening. The domestic scene had become a disaster zone, and he, for all his social grace, felt as ill-equipped as a civilian at a five-alarm fire. He moved quietly, filling the kettle and setting it to boil, the mundane act a small anchor in the swirling emotional storm.

“He wants to join the army,” she finally choked out, her words muffled by her palms. She lifted her head, her face blotchy and ravaged with grief. “He wants to follow his father. To the letter.” She gestured wildly at the smoothed-out pamphlet on the counter, as if it were the author of all her pain. “That same picture, that same promise of a ‘challenge’. Your step-father, Robert, he had a folder full of them. He’d look at them the way other men look at… I don’t know. Cars. Women. He saw it as a calling. I saw it as a death wish.”

Marcus placed a mug of steaming tea in front of her, his movements gentle. He sat down opposite her, his usual easy confidence replaced by a sombre patience. He didn’t speak, letting her fill the silence. He had been a teenager when Robert died, old enough to remember the taut anxiety in the house, the stilted, long-distance phone calls, and the final, crushing visit from the men in uniform. He remembered Sarah’s silence, a heavy, suffocating blanket that had covered the house for months.

“I thought we were past it,” she continued, her voice trembling as she wrapped her cold hands around the warm mug. “I thought when Lachie joined the fire brigade, that would be enough for him. That need he has… that need to run towards the danger. It’s his father in him. I thought he could do it here, where I could see him. Where he comes home at the end of his shift, smelling of smoke and not… not sand and cordite. But it’s not enough. He called it a circular holding pattern. A janitor’s job.” Her voice broke on a bitter laugh. “He saves people from burning to death in their own beds and he thinks it’s mundane.”

Outside in the darkness, Lachlan’s hands were white-knuckled on the steering wheel. He could feel the vibrations of the house through the soles of his boots, the phantom thrum of the argument. His mother’s words echoed in his skull, sharper than any crackle of comms. *Don’t be a boy chasing his father’s ghost into a grave!* Was that what this was? He’d always told himself it was different. His father had been an infantryman, a grunt on the front lines in a conflict the world had already half-forgotten. Lachlan’s own aspirations felt more defined, more skilled. He’d been looking at Combat Engineer roles, specialist positions. Building, clearing, defusing. A different kind of fight. But was it? Or was it just a different flavour of the same impulse, the same gaping need his father had carried to his grave?

With a sudden, violent twist, he turned the key. The ute’s diesel engine rumbled to life, its gruff voice filling the quiet suburban street. Through the windscreen, he saw the flicker of movement in the living room window. He knew they could hear him. He knew this sound was another blow, the sound of him choosing the horizon over the hearth. He put the truck in gear and pulled away from the curb, not looking back. The houses slid by, neat brick veneers and tidy gardens, islands of peaceful slumber. Each one felt like a judgment. He was the restless wolf, pacing the edges of the flock, unable to find a place within it. The smell of the fire, of burned plastic and charred wood, was his element. This quiet, ordered peace felt alien.

Back in the kitchen, the sound of the ute’s engine fading into the distance was a physical blow to Sarah. She flinched, a fresh wave of tears spilling down her cheeks. “He’s gone.”

“He’ll be back,” Marcus said, though he wasn’t entirely certain. He looked at the crumpled pamphlet again. He understood Lachlan, perhaps better than Sarah could allow herself to. Marcus had chosen art, culture, the careful restoration of beautiful things. Lachlan had chosen the opposite: a direct, brutal confrontation with chaos. They were two sides of a coin, each seeking a way to impose order on the world—Marcus by curating it, Lachlan by wrestling it into submission. But he also saw the trap. He saw the allure of the simple, noble narrative the army sold. A clear enemy, a clear purpose. It was a powerful antidote to the messy, mundane reality of putting out fires in chip pans.

“He thinks Robert was a hero,” Sarah whispered, staring into her tea as if reading the future in the leaves. “And he was. He was brave, and he was good. But his heroism didn’t keep him alive. It didn’t bring him home to his son. It just left a hole. A big, ragged hole that Lachlan has been trying to fill his entire life. First with adrenaline, now… now with this. He’s not trying to be a hero, Marcus. He’s trying to meet a ghost.”

The ute’s headlights cut a swathe through the darkness, illuminating familiar roads that felt alien and hostile. He didn’t drive aimlessly. He drove with a cold purpose, up the winding road that led out of town, climbing towards King’s Lookout. It was a place for teenage lovers and tourists, a clichéd vantage point, but tonight its appeal was literal. It was a place to get above it all, to see the borders of the world he was determined to leave. He parked at the gravelled edge, the engine ticking as it cooled, and stepped out into a wind that had a serrated edge. Below him, the town was a predictable grid of orange and white lights, a blanket of manufactured safety thrown over thousands of sleeping lives.

From up here, the scale of it all felt manageable, almost pathetic. Each light represented a home, a box full of flammable possessions and fragile relationships. He could see the faint glow in the direction of his own street, a pinpoint of light that was his mother, sitting in a kitchen that was no longer a sanctuary but a cage. He knew the town’s secrets, the geography of its small-scale tragedies. He knew the house on Elm Street had a faulty flue and the takeaway on the corner left their fryers on too long. He was a custodian of these mundane dangers, the keeper of a hundred tiny, preventable apocalypses. The thought filled him with a profound and weary disgust. The town wasn't a community to be protected; it was a patient with a chronic, self-inflicted illness he was tired of treating.

His mother’s words came back to him, carried on the wind. *A boy chasing his father’s ghost.* He kicked a loose stone and watched it skitter over the edge into the blackness. She was wrong. It wasn’t about his father; not really. It was about the hollowness inside him, the space where the adrenaline used to sing. That space was a vacuum now, and nature abhors a vacuum. He needed to fill it with something bigger, something with a clearer objective than a smouldering mattress. The army wasn't a ghost. It was a structure, a meritocracy of courage. It was a ladder, not a wheel. He wouldn't be mopping up the messes of other people’s carelessness. He would be on the sharp end of a defined mission, a part of something with consequence. It felt clean, simple, and honest in a way that his current life did not.

Back in the house, the mug of tea sat untouched, a skin forming on its surface. Marcus watched Sarah, her hands twisting a loose thread on her dressing gown, her gaze fixed on the ghost of Lachlan’s presence in the empty chair. The silence was brittle, ready to shatter. He had to say something, but the right words felt like a foreign language. He was a man who solved problems with grant applications and seating plans, not with raw, familial grief. Still, he had to try. He cleared his throat, the sound unnaturally loud.

“He gets it from Robert, you know,” Marcus said, his voice softer than he intended. “Not just the recklessness. The focus. I remember Robert planning things. Whether it was building the back deck or preparing for a deployment, it was all he could see. Everything else just… faded into the background. Lachlan’s the same. He’s locked onto this. Right now, to him, it’s the only real thing in the world.”

“But it’s a fantasy,” Sarah whispered, finally looking at him. Her eyes were full of a desperate, pleading logic. “They sell it as a team, as a brotherhood, but Robert was never lonelier than when he was in the army. He’d come home on leave and he was a stranger in his own house. He couldn’t talk about what he’d seen, and he couldn’t understand why we were all worried about the rates or what was on telly. He was there, but he was gone. He was a ghost long before they sent him home in a box. I’m not just afraid of losing Lachlan to a bullet, Marcus. I’m afraid of losing him right here, in this room, while he’s still breathing.”

Marcus listened, his earlier glibness completely stripped away. He saw the full shape of her terror now, and it was far more complex than a mother’s simple fear. It was the dread of a recurring history, a pattern she was powerless to break. He picked up the crumpled pamphlet again, studying the determined face of the soldier. “I don’t think you can talk him out of it,” he said, choosing his words with immense care. “Arguing with him is like trying to argue with a fire. It just feeds it. He feels misunderstood, and that just proves his point that he doesn’t belong here.” He paused, looking from the pamphlet to her. “But he’s not his father. He’s your son. He’s not a ghost. He’s angry and he’s lost, and maybe he needs someone to see that, instead of just seeing Robert’s shadow.”

Lachlan sat in his ute, the view of the town doing nothing to quiet the storm inside him. The cold was beginning to seep into his bones, a familiar ache that always followed the heat of a fire and the crash from the adrenaline. He was tired of circles. The argument with his mother, the drive up here, the hollow feeling in his chest—it was all part of the same loop. Action was the only way to break it. He pulled out his phone, the screen’s bright light making the dark cabin feel even smaller, more confining. His fingers, still faintly stained with soot around the nails, felt clumsy on the sleek glass. He ignored the missed call from Gaz and a text message that was probably from Marcus. He opened the browser, the search bar blinking expectantly. With a sense of grim finality, he typed the words he’d been thinking for months. *Australian Army Recruitment.*

The website loaded, crisp and professional. It was a world away from the greasy weight of smoke and the chaos of a house fire. Here, everything was orderly. Pathways. Opportunities. Challenges. The words were like a balm on his raw nerves. He found the "Apply Now" button without hesitation. It led to a form, a series of simple, logical boxes to be filled. Name. Date of birth. Contact details. Each one was a small, declarative statement, a step away from the life spread out in the darkness below him and towards the anonymous, focused horizon he craved. He filled in the fields, his personal history reduced to data. The smell of ash and burned timber still clung to him, a scent from a life that already felt like it belonged to someone else. He reached the end of the page. A single button waited. *Submit Expression of Interest.* He took a breath, the cold air stinging his lungs, and pressed it. The click was silent, digital, but in the quiet of the ute, it sounded as loud and as final as a chambered round.

A sterile confirmation page replaced the form. *Thank you for your interest. A recruitment officer will be in contact with you shortly.* The words were utterly devoid of emotion, a bland corporate sign-off for a decision that had torn his world in two. For a long moment, Lachlan felt nothing at all. The roiling anger, the suffocating sense of being trapped, the desperate need for escape—it all vanished, leaving behind a silence as profound and empty as the valley below. The click had been a release valve. The pressure was gone, and in its place, a strange, floaty calm. He had acted. He had broken the circle. He stared out at the grid of lights, no longer seeing a judgment or a cage, but simply a place. A place he was leaving. The thought didn't bring triumph, just a quiet, settled certainty.

He drove back down the winding road, the ute’s tyres crunching on the gravel. The descent felt symbolic, a return to the messy lowlands of human affairs, but he felt detached from it now, an observer. He couldn't go home. The thought of walking back into that kitchen, of seeing his mother’s shattered face and the well-meaning concern in Marcus’s eyes, was impossible. It would be like trying to explain the physics of a backdraft to someone who had never felt the heat. They wouldn’t understand the necessity of it. They would only see the destruction. There was only one other place he could go. He found himself turning not towards his own quiet street, but towards the slightly more chaotic, lived-in suburb where Gaz lived.

Gaz’s house was a modest brick bungalow, the lawn cluttered with the detritus of family life: a soccer ball, a small, pink bicycle with training wheels, and a deflated paddling pool. A single light burned in the living room window. Lachlan cut the engine and sat for a moment in the darkness, the ordinariness of the scene a stark contrast to the monumental decision humming in his veins. This was the life he was supposed to want. The wife, the kids, the mortgage, the slow march towards a pension. It was the life his mother had prayed for him to have. To Lachlan, it looked like a different kind of trap, its walls just softer and more pleasantly decorated. He got out of the ute, the smell of smoke that still clung to him feeling like an unwelcome intrusion in this peaceful suburban night.

He knocked softly, not wanting to wake Gaz’s wife or their two young kids. A few moments later, the door opened. Gaz stood there in a faded band t-shirt and shorts, his face etched with concern. He didn’t look surprised to see him. He simply stepped back and held the door open. “Knew you wouldn’t go home. Come on in. The kettle’s on.” The inside of the house smelled of laundry powder, baby shampoo, and the faint, sweet scent of a leftover birthday cake he could see on the kitchen counter. It was the smell of a life Lachlan felt he had no right to disturb.

Gaz didn’t press. He just made two mugs of tea, moving around his kitchen with the same unhurried competence he showed on a fire ground. He pushed one across the table to Lachlan and sat down, his expression patient. He was waiting for the story. The silence stretched, filled only by the low hum of the same model of refrigerator that was humming in his mother’s kitchen. “Saw you took off,” Gaz said finally, his voice low. “Your mum looked… well, she looked how you’d expect.”

Lachlan stared into his mug, the rising steam blurring the tired lines on his face. “We had a fight.”

“Reckon that’s the understatement of the year, mate,” Gaz replied, taking a slow sip of tea. He watched Lachlan over the rim of his mug. “She found the pamphlets, didn’t she? The ones you’ve been stashing in your locker.”

Lachlan’s head snapped up, surprise momentarily cutting through his exhaustion. Gaz just gave a small, sad smile. “Lachie, I’m your partner. I know you better than you think. I know you’ve been itching for something else. I see how you look at the jobs. Like they’re an insult. I just hoped you’d grow out of it.” He put his mug down with a soft click. “So, you did it, then? You signed up?”

The question was direct, with no judgment attached, but it carried the weight of their shared history, of every fire they’d fought together. “I submitted my interest online,” Lachlan admitted, the words feeling small and inadequate. “Tonight. Up at the lookout.”

Gaz nodded slowly, absorbing the information. He ran a hand over his tired face, the roadmap of wrinkles deepening. He didn’t look angry, just weary. “And what do you think that’s going to solve? You think a different uniform is going to fill that hole you’re carrying around? War isn’t a neat and tidy mission, mate. It’s just a bigger, messier fire. The enemy isn’t complacency; it’s just some other poor bastard who’s been told you’re the enemy. There’s no dragon to slay there, either.”

“It’s not like that anymore,” Lachlan argued, the recruiter’s words already forming on his lips. “It’s about specialist skills. Rebuilding, peacekeeping, strategic objectives. It’s not just… running at people with guns.”

“Isn’t it?” Gaz’s gaze was sharp. “That kid’s tricycle tonight. The one that melted on the driveway. The family lost everything, but they’re alive. They’re alive because we went in when every sane person was running out. We did that. You and me. We stood between them and a pretty bloody awful death. You tell me that’s not a worthwhile challenge. You tell me that’s not a consequence. You might feel like a janitor, but to that family, you’re the only thing that mattered in the whole world tonight. Don’t you ever forget that.” He leaned back in his chair, the argument made. He wasn't trying to stop Lachlan. He was simply holding up a mirror, forcing him to look at the value of the life he was so desperate to discard.

Gaz’s words landed with the solid weight of truth, a different kind of brute force from the hose nozzle. They didn’t knock Lachlan back; they settled deep inside him, a heavy, uncomfortable ballast in the hollow space in his chest. He had no counter-argument. The image of the family, safe on the curb, their faces streaked with tears and soot, was the bedrock of his job. To call it mundane was a betrayal, not just of them, but of the man sitting opposite him, a man who had pulled him clear of a collapsing roof joist two years ago without a moment’s hesitation. Lachlan couldn’t meet his partner’s gaze. He just stared at the swirling eddies of steam rising from his mug, a miniature, harmless chaos.

“I know,” Lachlan said, his voice barely a whisper. The admission felt like a defeat. “I know all that, Gaz. But it’s still there. The feeling. It’s like I’m running on a treadmill. I run all night, I sweat, I ache, but I haven’t gone anywhere.” He finally looked up, his eyes pleading for an understanding that he himself didn’t fully possess. “Up at the lookout, I felt… calm. For the first time in months. After I clicked the button. Like I’d finally chosen a direction. Any direction.”

Gaz sighed, a long, slow exhalation of air. It wasn't a sigh of frustration, but of a deep, paternal sadness. He had seen this kind of desperate restlessness before, in new recruits who burned out too fast, chasing a glory that didn’t exist. “A direction chosen in the middle of the night after a bad fire and a fight with your mum isn’t a direction, Lachie. It’s an escape hatch. And you don’t know what’s on the other side of it.” He pushed his chair back and stood, collecting their empty mugs. “You can’t go home tonight. The spare room’s full of Carla’s sewing stuff, but the couch is clear. Get some sleep. Things look different in the morning.”

The offer was a lifeline, and Lachlan grabbed it. He mumbled his thanks, feeling like an intruder in the quiet sanctuary of his friend’s home. Gaz simply clapped him on the shoulder, a solid, reassuring weight, before disappearing down the hall to fetch a pillow and a blanket. Lachlan was left alone in the kitchen, the evidence of a happy, chaotic life all around him. A child’s drawing of a lopsided fire truck was stuck to the fridge with a magnet. A half-finished puzzle sat on a side table. These were the things people saved from fires. These were the things he was running from.

He woke to a world he didn't belong in. The morning light slanting through the living room window was gentle, filtered through the leaves of a large gum tree. The sounds were soft, domestic. The distant clatter of a plastic bowl hitting the floor, followed by a giggle. The low murmur of Gaz’s voice, not the clipped, professional tone of the fire ground, but a soft, rumbling cadence as he negotiated with a toddler. The smell of toast and coffee filled the air. Lachlan lay perfectly still on the couch, the blanket pulled up to his chin, feeling like a spy in a foreign country. This was the life that ran in parallel to his own, the ‘why’ behind Gaz’s steady presence at his side in a burning building. To be in the heart of it felt like a trespass.

Quietly, he folded the blanket and placed it neatly on the arm of the couch. He scribbled a thank-you note on the back of an old receipt from his wallet and left it on the kitchen counter, next to the birthday cake. He let himself out the front door as silently as he had arrived, the click of the latch sounding like a gunshot in the morning quiet. The cool air was a relief, washing away the cloying intimacy of the house. He got into his ute, the familiar smell of smoke and stale coffee a grim comfort. He was back in his own territory. He drove away just as Gaz’s daughter, a tiny thing with her father’s curly hair, came running to the front window to see who was leaving.

He spent the morning in limbo, driving the streets of the town with no destination. He couldn’t go to the station and face Gaz again, not yet. He couldn’t go home. He was a ghost in his own life, haunting the periphery. He bought a coffee from a drive-through and parked by the river, watching a lone rower slice through the flat, grey water. Each pull of the oars was a picture of singular focus, a rhythm of effort and glide. He felt a pang of envy. His own efforts felt so scattered, so reactive. The phone buzzed in the centre console, a harsh, electric sound that broke the spell. The screen lit up with a number he didn’t recognise, a Sydney area code. His heart gave a hard, single thump against his ribs. He knew who it was.

He let it ring three times, his hand hovering over the device. This was it. The moment the abstract became real. He could ignore it. He could throw the phone in the river and drive home, tell his mother she was right, and spend the rest of his life wondering. Or he could answer. He took a breath that tasted of cheap coffee and apprehension, and tapped the screen. “Lachlan Jones speaking.”

The voice on the other end was clipped, cheerful, and utterly impersonal. A young woman who sounded like she was reading from a script. “Good morning, Mr. Jones. My name is Corporal Davies from Defence Force Recruiting. I’m calling in response to the expression of interest you submitted online for a role in the Australian Army. Do you have a moment to talk?”

“Yes. I do,” Lachlan said, his own voice sounding distant, as if it were coming from someone else.

“Excellent. The first step in the process is to attend a YOU Session—that’s a Your Opportunities Unlimited session—at one of our recruiting centres. It involves an aptitude test, a medical review, and a chat with a career coach to discuss your potential roles. We have a session running at our Parramatta centre next Tuesday at 0900 hours. Is that something you would be able to attend?”

The world outside the ute’s windscreen seemed to shrink and sharpen. The rower, the river, the trees on the far bank—it all became a backdrop. The only thing that was real was the question hanging in the air. Tuesday. It was a date on a calendar, a fixed point on the horizon he had been so desperate to find. It was a door, and all he had to do was agree to walk through it. The silence stretched for a beat too long.

“Mr. Jones? Are you still there?”

“Yes,” he said, his throat dry. “Yes, Tuesday is fine. I’ll be there.”

He ended the call and tossed the phone onto the passenger seat. For a moment, the world remained a two-dimensional backdrop. Then, sound and colour flooded back in with a rush. The gentle lapping of the river against the reedy bank. The rhythmic creak of the rower’s oars. The earthy smell of damp soil and river water. The decision, now locked into a specific time and place, had acted like a tectonic shift, rearranging his entire inner landscape. The rage and restlessness were gone, replaced by a strange, hollowed-out calm. The path ahead was no longer a frantic search for a horizon; it was a train journey to Parramatta. It was an appointment in a diary. The mundane bureaucracy of it was strangely soothing. He had made his choice. Now all he had to do was walk the line.

The drive home was an exercise in deferred dread. He rehearsed conversations in his head, defensive justifications and clipped, evasive answers, but he knew words were useless now. He had moved beyond negotiation. He pulled into the driveway, his ute’s engine sounding like a desecration in the quiet afternoon. The house looked exactly the same, but it felt like a foreign embassy, a place where he was no longer a citizen. He took a deep breath, the air still clean and free, and walked towards the front door. He was a visitor now, and he had come to announce his departure.

Sarah was in the living room, sitting in her armchair, not reading or watching television, just sitting. The house was unnaturally tidy, a sign of anxious energy channelled into meaningless tasks. She looked up as he entered, her face a pale, exhausted mask. There were dark circles under her eyes, and he knew with a gut-punch of guilt that she hadn’t slept. The air between them was thick and heavy, a physical presence like the smoke from the fire.

“Marcus went home,” she said, her voice flat and devoid of emotion. It wasn’t an accusation, just a statement of fact. “He was worried. Gaz called, too. He said you were at his place.”

“I didn’t want to wake you,” Lachlan replied, the excuse sounding lame even to his own ears. He remained standing in the doorway, unwilling to enter the room, to sit down, to pretend that anything was normal. He knew she was looking for a sign, any crack in his resolve, any hint that the night had softened him. He couldn’t give it to her. He had to be a wall, for both their sakes.

Her gaze swept over him, taking in his rigid posture, the set of his jaw. Her shoulders slumped in a gesture of profound defeat. She knew. He didn’t have to say a word. “So that’s it, then,” she whispered, her eyes drifting to the window, to the quiet, safe street beyond. “You’ve made your mind up.”

“Mum…” he started, but the word died in his throat. There was nothing to say.
