Men were scattered around, cleaning weapons, servicing vehicles, and engaging in the time-honoured military tradition of drinking copious amounts of tea while complaining about their superiors. Lachlan stood awkwardly near the entrance until a corporal with a neat, compact build and a calm, authoritative air approached him. His name tape read ‘FRANKS’. “Sapper Jones,” he stated, his voice quiet but firm. “I’m Corporal Franks, your section commander. Welcome to Three Troop.” He shook Lachlan’s hand, his grip strong and dry. “Your roommate Dingo will show you the ropes, get you squared away at the Q-store. We’re on vehicle maintenance for the rest of the week. Don’t touch anything until you’re told to, don’t break anything, and if you’ve got nothing to do, find a broom. Clear?” “Clear, Corporal,” Lachlan replied, the familiar response feeling solid and reassuring.

The rest of the day was a blur of mundane, essential tasks. He was introduced to the Troop Sergeant, a grizzled veteran with a face like a clenched fist who looked at him as if he were something unpleasant he’d scraped off his boot. He met the Troop Commander, a fresh-faced Lieutenant who seemed barely older than Travers and spoke with the clipped, eager enthusiasm of someone who had read all the right books but had yet to face a real test. Led by a laconic Dingo, he spent hours in the quartermaster's store, a vast, dim warehouse, being issued a mountain of new equipment specific to the tropical environment and his engineering role. He signed for everything from mosquito nets and water purification tablets to specialised demolition kits and mine detectors. Each signature was another link in the chain binding him to this new life. The work itself, back at the troop lines, was unglamorous. He found himself cleaning mud from the tracks of an armoured personnel carrier, the repetitive, mindless task a stark contrast to the high-minded purpose he had felt on graduation day. He was a janitor again, just in a different uniform, mopping up the messes of a different machine.

That night, alone in his room while Dingo was out with friends, the full weight of his dislocation settled upon him. The oppressive heat, the constant hum of the air-conditioner, the sterile anonymity of the room, and the cynical, closed-off nature of his new colleagues all conspired to make him feel more isolated than ever before. He was a thousand miles from home, a stranger in a strange land, and the clear, simple purpose he had clung to during training felt distant and hazy. He pulled a writing pad from his locker, intending to write to his mother, but stared at the blank page, a familiar paralysis taking hold. How could he describe this life? The boredom, the casual cynicism, the overwhelming sense of being a novice in a world of hardened experts? He couldn’t tell her about Dingo’s casual profanity or the Troop Sergeant’s look of utter contempt. He couldn’t explain the feeling of being utterly insignificant. So he fell back on the facts, the sterile language of a military report. *Arrived safely in Darwin. The base is big. I’ve been assigned to my troop. The work is interesting.* He sealed the letter, the words feeling like a betrayal of his own reality.

Frustrated, he picked up the poetry book. He let it fall open to a random page and his eyes fell on a poem he hadn't noticed before, "A Bush Christening," about a rough-and-tumble outback family. There was a faint pencil mark next to a line describing the father: *“He was none of your dolts, he was sharp as a needle.”* Lachlan sat back, considering the line. It wasn't about being strong or brave. It was about being sharp, about being switched-on, about surviving in an environment that punished foolishness. He looked around the sterile room, at the pile of unfamiliar, technical equipment he had been issued, and thought of Corporal Franks’ quiet competence, Dingo’s cynical but observant nature, the Troop Sergeant's unspoken demand for absolute professionalism. This wasn't Kapooka, where the challenge was to endure. This was a different kind of test. The challenge here was to be sharp. To learn, to observe, to prove that he was not a dolt, but a useful, competent part of the team. The road forward wasn't a grand, heroic charge; it was a slow, patient accumulation of knowledge and trust, one mundane task at a time. The loneliness didn't disappear, but a new, clearer sense of purpose began to crystallise within it. He was not here to be a hero. He was here to be a Sapper. And the education had just begun.

The education of a Sapper began not with a bang, but with a broom. Every morning, after a run in the soupy, pre-dawn humidity that left him feeling like he was drowning on dry land, Lachlan’s first duty was to sweep the vast concrete floor of the troop shed. He was the newest arrival, the ‘chock’, a term he’d learned meant a raw, inexperienced soldier, and therefore the designated custodian of menial tasks. While the veteran Sappers gathered around the large, battered urn for their first mug of tea, their conversation a low, cynical murmur, Lachlan would push the wide broom, collecting a film of red dust, grease, and the detritus of the previous day’s work. He didn't resent it. He understood its purpose. It was a tax he had to pay for entry, and it gave him the perfect opportunity to do what he did best: observe. He learned the names of the other men in his section not through formal introductions, but by listening to the banter. There was ‘Dingo’ O’Connell, his cynical roommate; ‘Knuckles’ Petrie, a slab of a man with a shaved head and a surprisingly gentle touch with delicate electronics; and ‘Shades’ Williams, a quiet, wiry Sapper who never seemed to be without his wraparound sunglasses, even indoors. And then there was Corporal Franks, their section commander, who moved through the morning chaos with a quiet, watchful economy, his presence a low hum of authority that didn't require a raised voice.

The work itself was a slow, grinding immersion in the tools of his new trade. Days were spent on vehicle maintenance, a greasy, frustrating education in the guts of armoured personnel carriers, generators, and outboard motors. Dingo became his begrudging instructor, a fount of cynical, hard-won knowledge. "If you round off a bolt, the Boomer will use it to screw your head back on straight," he’d mutter, watching Lachlan struggle with a seized nut. "Never stand behind an excavator when Knuckles is driving. And if you have to choose between getting wet and getting electrocuted, take the wet." The advice was always delivered with a world-weary sigh, as if the effort of passing on wisdom to someone so clueless was almost too much to bear. But Lachlan listened. He learned to differentiate the healthy roar of a diesel engine from the unhealthy clatter that preceded a breakdown. He learned the feel of a properly torqued bolt, the precise language of the technical manuals, and, most importantly, when to ask a question and when to keep his mouth shut and figure it out for himself.

The mystery of the ‘Boomer’ was solved in his first week. The Troop Sergeant, a man whose permanent scowl seemed to be a load-bearing feature of his face, was conducting a spot inspection of their work. He stopped at a Land Rover where Knuckles had just finished servicing the brakes. For a full minute, the Sergeant stared at the wheel hub in absolute silence, his stillness drawing the attention of the entire shed. Then he reached out a single, thick finger and tapped the brake calliper. “Petrie,” he said, his voice a low, gravelly rasp. “You’ve used a grade five bolt on this calliper mount. The manual specifies a grade eight. Do you know the difference in shear strength between a grade five and a grade eight bolt?” Knuckles, who dwarfed the Sergeant, seemed to shrink, his face turning a mottled red. “No, Sergeant,” he stammered. The Sergeant leaned in close. “It’s the difference between this vehicle stopping at the bottom of a hill, or you and your mates becoming a new coat of paint on a rock wall. It’s the difference between a soldier and a liability. Now, which one are you?” He didn't wait for an answer. He simply turned and walked away. A cold silence descended on the shed. Later, as Lachlan was cleaning grease from his hands with a solvent-soaked rag, Dingo leaned against the workbench. “That,” he said quietly, “is the Boomer. That’s why you don’t fuck up.”

Lachlan’s first small test, when it came, was over a piece of equipment so insignificant it was almost laughable. The section was preparing for a riverine exercise, and one of the Zodiac’s outboard motors was proving temperamental. It would start perfectly, run for ten minutes, then sputter and die for no apparent reason. Dingo and Shades had pulled the carburettor apart twice, their curses growing more creative with each failure. Corporal Franks stood watching, his arms crossed, his expression one of patient frustration. Lachlan, tasked with cleaning the boat’s inflatable pontoons, was on the periphery, but his ears were tuned to the problem. The symptoms were naggingly familiar. It was like a fire that kept flaring up in a wall cavity; there was a hidden fuel source, a hidden fault in the system. He put down his sponge and walked over, his heart thumping with the fear of overstepping his mark. “Corporal,” he began, his voice hesitant. Franks turned his steady gaze on him. Dingo shot him a look that said, *don’t you dare*. Lachlan pushed on. “When a two-stroke runs fine then cuts out when it’s hot, sometimes it means a failing crank seal. It’s drawing air when the casing expands, leaning out the fuel mix.” He had seen the same principle a dozen times with the petrol-powered rescue saws at the fire station.

A heavy silence fell over the small group. Dingo scoffed. “It’s a brand-new motor, chock. The seals are fine.” But Franks didn’t dismiss it. He looked from Lachlan to the motor, his brow furrowed in thought. “How would we test that theory?” he asked, his question directed squarely at Lachlan. The direct engagement was both terrifying and exhilarating. “When it’s hot and running rough, you can spray a bit of starter fluid around the crankcase housing. If the revs pick up, it’s sucking the fluid in through a bad seal.” It was a bush mechanic’s trick, a piece of practical knowledge from a different life. Franks considered this for a moment, then nodded. “Alright. Let’s try it.” They ran the motor until it began to sputter. As instructed, Franks gave a quick, targeted spray of aerosol starter fluid near the crankcase. The engine, which had been on the verge of dying, suddenly screamed back to life for a few seconds before faltering again. The proof was undeniable. Dingo stared at the motor, then at Lachlan, his mouth slightly agape. Corporal Franks straightened up and wiped his hands on a rag. “Good spot, Jones,” he said, the words delivered with no more inflection than a weather report. He then turned to Dingo. “Pull it apart. Get a new seal kit from stores.” For the rest of the day, Lachlan felt a quiet, internal hum of satisfaction. He had been sharp. He had been useful.

That evening, as the section was packing up, Dingo paused at the door of their donga. Lachlan was sitting on his bunk, cleaning his rifle, the familiar, methodical task a comfort at the end of a long day. “Oi, Jones,” Dingo called out. “Me and the boys are heading to the boozer for a counter meal. You coming?” The invitation was gruff, almost a challenge, but it was an invitation all the same. It was the first time he had been included. Lachlan looked up from his rifle, a slow smile spreading across his face. “Yeah,” he said, trying to match the casual, offhand tone. “Yeah, righto.” As he followed Dingo out into the warm, insect-rich twilight, he felt a lightness he hadn't experienced since he had left home. The loneliness was still a quiet hum in the background, but for the first time, it was being drowned out by the feeling that he was, finally, exactly where he was supposed to be.

The pub, a cavernous, air-conditioned shed just off base, was an extension of the troop lines, only with more alcohol and fewer rules. The section claimed a corner table, their collective presence creating an invisible perimeter that other soldiers instinctively respected. The conversation flowed around Lachlan, a raw, cynical stream of complaints about the food, the officers, the heat, and the sheer, bloody stupidity of a recent directive from on high. It was a litany of grievances that served as a form of social glue. Dingo held court, his stories punctuated by dry wit and a flair for the dramatic. Knuckles would interject with a low rumble of agreement, while Shades, true to his name, observed from behind his sunglasses, offering only a rare, wry smile.

Lachlan mostly listened, nursing a cold beer, a student of this new culture. He learned that the Troop Sergeant’s nickname, ‘The Boomer’, came from his previous service in a mortar platoon. He learned that the Lieutenant was known derisively as ‘The Textbook’ because his every decision seemed to come from a manual rather than experience. He learned that the unspoken code of the Sapper was to complain relentlessly about the work, but to take immense, ferocious pride in its execution. He was an outsider listening in, but for the first time, he was an outsider who had been invited inside the circle.

“So, Jonesy,” Knuckles rumbled, turning his attention to Lachlan for the first time that evening. The use of a nickname, however generic, was a significant step. “Dingo reckons you’re some kind of engine whisperer. Used to be a grease monkey?”

“Firefighter,” Lachlan corrected, the word feeling strange on his tongue. “Worked with a lot of two-stroke rescue gear. Saws, pumps. They’re all temperamental bastards.”

“Firefighter, eh?” Shades spoke up, his voice a surprising baritone. He took a slow sip of his beer. “So you’re used to running into burning buildings. Explains why you’d volunteer for this gig. Got a death wish?” The question was blunt, but it lacked malice. It was a genuine inquiry.

Lachlan considered the question. A few months ago, it would have stung, a direct hit on a raw nerve. Now, it felt like a question about a different person. “Something like that,” he admitted with a shrug. “Got tired of mopping up messes. Figured I’d rather build something for a change.”

“We don’t build things, mate,” Dingo snorted, slamming his empty glass on the table. “We blow things up. Then maybe, if The Textbook draws the plans right, we build something out of the wreckage. It’s a cleaner kind of mess, that’s all.” He grinned, a flash of white teeth in his tanned face. “But the pay’s alright and the explosions are pretty. Another round?” As Lachlan nodded, he realised he had passed another, unspoken test. He had given an honest, unvarnished answer that fit their cynical worldview. He wasn’t trying to be a hero. He was just another bloke looking for a cleaner mess. The small act of Dingo getting the next round was a confirmation. He was in.

The "cleaner mess" arrived a week later in the form of Exercise Sapper’s Strike. The objective was simple and brutal: to destroy a series of obsolete concrete structures deep in the Mount Bundey Training Area, a vast, heat-scorched territory south of the base. The structures, remnants of a Cold War-era radar station, were thick, reinforced bunkers, designed to withstand everything short of a direct nuclear strike. Their task was to reduce them to rubble, a practical test of their demolition theory.

The approach to the site was a mission in itself. They moved in a small convoy, their Land Rovers churning up clouds of fine red dust that coated everything in a gritty film. The landscape was primordial, a flat, savanna-like plain punctuated by towering termite mounds that looked like a thousand silent, red sentinels. The heat was a living entity, pressing down on the canvas roof of the vehicle, radiating up from the metal floor. Corporal Franks briefed them at the site, his voice sharp and precise against the backdrop of the incessant chirping of cicadas. He pointed to the first objective, a low, squat concrete bunker half-swallowed by the encroaching bush. “This is Bunker Alpha. Your task is to calculate and place charges for a complete structural collapse. You will use PE4 plastic explosive with a dual-primed ring main. Lachlan, you’re on calculations and charge prep. Dingo, you and Knuckles will drill the charge holes. Shades, you’ll run the det cord. No mistakes. The Boomer and The Textbook will be observing from that ridge line.” He pointed to a low, stony rise a few hundred metres away, where two figures were already visible, small and menacing in the shimmering heat haze. “Do not make me look bad.”

Lachlan felt a knot of cold, focused excitement tighten in his stomach. This was it. The theory from the classroom, the dry formulas and blast ratios, were about to become a physical, violent reality. He knelt in the shade of a lone Woollybutt tree, his field notebook open, the plastic explosive cool and pliable in his hands. He calculated the volume and density of the concrete, factored in the reinforcing steel, and determined the precise mass of explosive needed for each charge. The process was a form of intricate, high-stakes mathematics. Too little, and they would only scar the bunker. Too much, and they would send shrapnel flying for a kilometre. He worked methodically, his hands moving with a new-found confidence as he moulded the PE4 into precisely weighed charges, carefully inserting the detonators, the small, potent hearts of the explosion.

As Dingo and Knuckles drilled into the thick concrete with a heavy, petrol-powered rock drill, its roar echoing across the plain, the sky began to change. The bleached-out blue darkened to a bruised purple on the horizon. The air grew heavy and still, the cicadas falling silent. “Build-up,” Shades muttered, nodding towards the approaching storm front. “She’s coming in fast.” The wet season was stirring, and its first storms were notoriously violent. The wind picked up, whipping dust and leaves into a frenzy. A few fat drops of rain splattered onto Lachlan’s notebook, smearing the ink. Franks swore under his breath. “Double time, let’s go! I want this rigged before the storm hits!”

The urgency escalated. The first crack of lightning split the sky, followed by a deafening clap of thunder that seemed to shake the very ground beneath their feet. The rain began in earnest, a torrential, blinding downpour that turned the red dust to a slick, greasy paste. Visibility dropped to a few metres. They were working in a primal chaos of wind and water. Lachlan, shielding his prepared charges with his own body, helped Shades run the det cord, their fingers numb and clumsy in the deluge. The cord, a thin, explosive line, had to be connected to each charge in a precise, unbroken sequence. A single faulty connection would compromise the entire shot. They scrambled back to the designated safe distance, unreeling the firing cable, their boots slipping and sliding in the treacherous mud. Crouched in a shallow ditch, Corporal Franks looked at each of them, his eyes intense. “All clear?” he yelled over the wind. One by one, they gave a thumbs-up. Franks took the electrical firing device, the ‘clacker’, and turned to Lachlan. “Your numbers, your shot, Jones.” He handed him the device. The responsibility was a physical weight in his hands. He took a deep, steadying breath, his heart pounding a rhythm against his ribs that matched the fury of the storm.

He knelt in the mud, the firing device feeling both alien and deeply familiar. It was a tool designed for a single, irreversible purpose. His world shrank to the small, red button under the protective guard. He ran through a final mental checklist: the calculations, the placement of the charges, the integrity of the ring main. He thought of the storm, the rain potentially compromising the connections. He thought of the two figures watching from the ridge, a jury of his superiors. He thought of his mother, a world away, and the photo of him as a boy on his father’s shoulders. Then he pushed it all aside. There was only the task, the science, and the trust placed in him by his section commander. He looked at Franks, who gave him a single, sharp nod. He lifted the guard, took one more breath to steady his hand, and yelled the ritual words into the roaring wind, a shout of defiance against the storm itself. “FIRE IN THE HOLE!” He squeezed the trigger.

For a split second, nothing happened. The world was just the drumming of the rain and the howl of the wind. Lachlan’s heart seized in a moment of cold, sickening dread. Had he failed? Then, the ground beneath them kicked, a violent, solid punch that travelled up through the soles of his boots and into his teeth. A deep, guttural *CRUMP* sound, more felt than heard, momentarily deadened all other noise. The bunker, which had stood impassively for half a century, seemed to swell from within. A web of cracks raced across its surface, and then it simply collapsed, folding in on itself like a house of cards in a silent, slow-motion ballet of destruction. A plume of grey dust and smoke, instantly beaten down by the torrential rain, rose from the wreckage. A beat later, the sound of the blast rolled back over them, a physical wave of pressure that flattened the grass and rattled their bones.

They lay in the ditch for a moment, the rain washing over them, the sudden silence where the bunker had been more profound than the noise that had preceded it. Dingo let out a low whistle. "Jesus, Jonesy. You don’t do things by halves, do you?" Lachlan felt a slow, shaky exhale leave his lungs, a breath he hadn't realised he was holding. He had done it. His numbers had been right. His hands, he noticed, were trembling, but not from fear. It was the pure, visceral aftermath of adrenaline, the same singing in his veins he had once felt after a fire, but this was different. It was the satisfaction of a job planned and perfectly executed. It was creation through destruction.

Corporal Franks clapped him on the shoulder, a hard, solid impact. "Good shot, Sapper," he said, the use of the formal title a mark of profound respect. He looked out at the pile of shattered concrete and twisted rebar. "Clean collapse. Minimal throw. The Boomer will be happy." The rain was already starting to ease, the storm passing as quickly as it had arrived. As they stood up, their bodies caked in mud, a rainbow, impossibly vivid, arched across the bruised sky directly over the site of the demolition. Knuckles let out a hoot of laughter. "Would you look at that? Even God likes a good explosion."

That evening, back at the barracks, the atmosphere was light, almost festive. They were exhausted, filthy, and facing hours of cleaning their sodden equipment, but they were buoyed by the shared success. The story of ‘Jonesy’s shot’ had already made its way around the troop lines, embellished with each telling. Lachlan found himself the quiet centre of a new level of acceptance. He was no longer just a competent mechanic; he was a Sapper who could be trusted when the stakes were high. As he sat on his bunk, painstakingly cleaning the red mud from the firing device, he felt a sense of belonging so deep it was almost painful. He had found his place, not in a safe, predictable life, but here, on the sharp edge, among these cynical, profane, and fiercely loyal men.

Later, before sleep, he pulled out his writing pad. The letter to his mother felt different tonight. He still couldn't describe the raw, visceral reality of his day, but he found new words. *We had a big training exercise today. It was a demolition task. It was my job to calculate the charges. It was complicated, but it went well. I’m learning a lot. The blokes in my section are good men. It’s hard work, but I think I’m good at it.* He paused, then added a line that was both a reassurance for her and a truth he was just beginning to accept for himself. *I feel like I’m finally building something.* He sealed the envelope and then, almost as an afterthought, he reached for his father's poetry book. He didn't open it to read. He simply placed his hand on the worn leather cover, feeling the solid weight of it in the darkness. The ghost of his father felt less like a shadow to be chased and more like a quiet, approving presence at his side. The road forward was no longer a abstract concept; it was a path he was walking, one explosion at a time.

The success of Exercise Sapper’s Strike bought Lachlan more than just a momentary feeling of accomplishment; it bought him a currency more valuable than pay in the ecosystem of the barracks: respect. He was no longer the ‘chock’ on broom duty. The broom was now the responsibility of a fresh-faced recruit just arrived from Kapooka, a kid with bewildered eyes who looked at Lachlan and the rest of the section with a mixture of terror and awe. Lachlan now joined the sacred morning ritual around the tea urn, a silent participant in the litany of complaints that served as the troop’s daily prayer. He learned to nod along as Dingo bemoaned the quality of the rations, to grunt in agreement when Knuckles cursed a piece of faulty equipment, and to appreciate the profound silence with which Shades could communicate his utter contempt for a newly issued directive. He was part of the circle, his entry fee paid in full with a perfectly executed demolition in the middle of a tropical thunderstorm.

The weeks that followed settled into a rhythm of intense training punctuated by long stretches of the peculiar boredom unique to army life. They practiced their core skills relentlessly. Days were spent on the ranges, the sharp crack of their rifles a constant, rhythmic punctuation to the oppressive heat. They rehearsed casualty evacuation under simulated fire, the drills so ingrained that they could apply a tourniquet or dress a wound with a mechanical, almost indifferent efficiency. Lachlan’s aptitude for the technical side of his trade continued to grow. Corporal Franks began to delegate more complex tasks to him, first under supervision, then with an unspoken trust. He learned the intricate wiring of command-detonated explosives, the delicate art of neutralising booby traps, and the patient, nerve-wracking process of searching for mines. He discovered he had a natural feel for the work, a combination of the firefighter's methodical risk assessment and a newfound soldier's discipline. His hands, which had once been calibrated to the heft of a Halligan bar, were now learning the delicate touch required to probe for a tripwire.

The announcement of their next major deployment came without fanfare during a morning briefing. The Platoon Sergeant, the Boomer, stood before them, his arms crossed over his chest, his presence casting a long shadow in the early morning light. The Textbook stood beside him, holding a clipboard and looking eager. The Boomer ignored him. “Listen up,” he growled, his voice cutting through the quiet murmur of the troop. “Two Platoon is being attached to Bravo Company from the 5th Battalion for Exercise Arnhem Thunder. It’s a full-spectrum combat team exercise. Infantry, armour, engineers, the whole circus.” He paused, letting the information sink in. “Our primary task is mobility support. Specifically, lane clearance. Bravo Company needs a safe path through a valley in the Litchfield Training Area. Intel suggests the valley is notionally mined. Your job is to clear it.” He scanned the faces of the assembled Sappers, his eyes lingering for a moment on Lachlan’s section. “One more thing,” he added, his voice dropping slightly. “This area was a major live-firing range during World War Two. It was never fully cleared. The ground here has a long memory. Keep your eyes open for anything that looks older than you are. Real-world unexploded ordnance is not notional. It will kill you just as dead. Franks, your section is lead element. Don’t stuff it up.”

The mood in the section shifted immediately. The casual cynicism was replaced by a quiet, focused professionalism. A notional minefield was a straightforward training task, a matter of following procedure. The potential for real, seventy-year-old UXO changed the entire equation. A training mine gives off a clear signal on a detector. A corroded, half-buried artillery shell from 1943 might give off nothing at all. It was a task that relied less on technology and more on instinct, observation, and pure, nerve-shredding luck. As they began the meticulous process of preparing their equipment, Lachlan watched Corporal Franks. The man’s calm demeanour never wavered, but there was a new intensity in his actions. He personally inspected every piece of their clearance gear, from the sensitive electronic heads of the mine detectors to the simple, non-metallic prodding rods. He checked the expiry dates on their demolition charges, the ones they would use to destroy any UXO they found. He was a man methodically preparing his tools for a task where a single mistake, a single moment of inattention, could vaporise his entire section. Lachlan felt a profound respect for the quiet, immense weight of responsibility Franks carried on his shoulders.

That afternoon, a new mail delivery arrived. Lachlan received a letter from his mother, and for the first time, he opened it without a sense of dread. The tone was different. The desperate, emotional pleas were gone, replaced by a sort of bruised acceptance. She wrote about her garden, about a funny thing Marcus had said, about how she’d seen Gaz’s wife at the supermarket. *Gaz said to tell you they’re all proud of you,* she wrote. The sentence stopped Lachlan short. Pride was not an emotion he had associated with his departure. She continued, asking practical questions about Darwin, about the food, about whether he was getting enough sleep. It was the letter of a mother learning to communicate with a son who now lived in a different country. But the final lines held the familiar, aching love that would always be the anchor of his old life. *I read your last letter to Marcus. He said it sounds like you’ve finally found what you were looking for. I hope he’s right. I pray for it every day. Just be safe, Lachie. Always be safe.* He folded the letter and put it carefully in his locker. He hadn’t found what he was looking for; he had built it, out of sweat and fear and the quiet approval of the men around him. And now, he had to prove he was worthy of it.

The final twenty-four hours before deployment were a quiet hum of activity. They drew their specialised gear, the mood in the Q-store more like a hospital dispensary than a supply depot. The mine detectors, with their long, sensitive arms, were treated with a reverence usually reserved for religious artifacts. They packed their webbing with marking tape, trip-flare indicators, and small, potent ‘Mecar’ charges designed for UXO disposal. The atmosphere was a world away from the boisterous energy that had preceded the demolition exercise. This was not a task that would end with a satisfying bang and a round of beers. This was quiet, patient, terrifying work. The enemy was not a reinforced bunker, but a ghost in the ground, a piece of rusted, unstable history waiting for a single misstep.

As the sun began to set, casting long, dramatic shadows across the barracks, Lachlan sat on his bunk, going through his own personal prep. He field-stripped and cleaned his rifle for the third time, the familiar, repetitive action a calming ritual. Heka sat opposite him, sharpening a large sheath knife on a whetstone, the rhythmic *shick-shick-shick* a steady, meditative sound in the quiet room. “You nervous, Jonesy?” Heka asked without looking up, his first unsolicited question in weeks. Lachlan paused his cleaning. “A bit,” he admitted. “You?” Heka stopped sharpening and looked at the blade, its edge gleaming in the low light. “Nervous is good,” he rumbled. “Nervous keeps you sharp. Scared gets you killed. There’s a difference.” He tested the blade on his thumb, nodded in satisfaction, and slid it back into its sheath. “This is the job, eh? To walk quiet. To look close. You’re good at that.” The simple statement of confidence from the big, silent man was more reassuring than any pep talk from an officer. It was an acknowledgment from one professional to another.

They were woken long before dawn. They moved in the darkness, their movements economical and sure, their gear making only the softest of sounds. They loaded into the back of a troop-carrier truck, the four men of the section sitting shoulder-to-shoulder on the hard bench seat. As the truck rumbled out of the barracks and onto the long, straight road leading to the training area, no one spoke. The first, pale light of dawn was beginning to illuminate the eastern sky. Lachlan looked at the faces around him, illuminated in the faint glow of the dashboard lights. Dingo’s cynical smirk was gone, replaced by a grim, focused intensity. Knuckles stared straight ahead, his jaw set. Shades was already wearing his sunglasses, a black, impenetrable mask. And Corporal Franks sat by the tailgate, his rifle across his lap, his gaze sweeping the passing landscape, already on the job. Lachlan felt a surge of cold, clear purpose. These were his men. This was his section. And they were heading into the valley, to clear the road forward, to walk quiet and look close, into a silence that held the memory of a long-forgotten war.
